text: hey guys it's angel today I have a very
special guest with me in my kitchen I
have my grandma here today and she is
going to help us make a Taiwanese style
thin noodle also known in Taiwanese as
meat swamp grandma can you come say
hello then I lighted it midni let's just
do a little uh okay so she that's head
bit camera shy but I'll have her come up
in a minute but before we get started I
wanted to share with you one special
ingredient this is actually a special
oil made in Taiwan and it is going to be
something that we are going to use in
these thin noodles now you may not have
heard of this before but is actually a
tea oil and in Taiwanese we call this
called au and it's literally the same
oil taken from the same plants used for
making drinking tea so it's very
aromatic and flavorful and a little bit
sweet compared to Western oils so with
that I will get my grandma up here and
let's get started first I'll boil a pot
of water because that always takes the
longest next I'll pass things off to my
grandma well I get behind the camera and
record this for you guys to start we'll
need some extra thin noodles and if you
haven't bought these dry noodles before
they're usually sold and bunched
together in two convenient serving sizes
one bunch of these thin noodles makes
two small bowls once your water has come
to a boil go ahead to add the noodles
and cook for three to five minutes or
until just done it really won't take
that long because these noodles are
super thin when they're done immediately
transfer them to a larger bowl for
mixing
next we'll add our three sauces start
with the tablespoon or two of our
specialty oil a drizzle of sesame oil
and finally one to two teaspoons of
low-sodium soy sauce feel free to use
less at first then building up to add
more taste as you go toss the noodles
and mix everything together really well
before transferring to your serving
bowls and finally if you have some fresh
garnish on hand you can always top with
a bit of fresh cilantro or scallions
so that's how easy it is to make these
Taiwanese style thin noodles now if
you're wondering this is typically
served for breakfast but it's so quick
and easy to make that I used to have
this all the time after school as an
after-school snack because it would only
take literally ten minutes to make so
very quick and easy and super delicious
now let me ask my grandma how it turned
